School of Management</depositr>         <depDate date="2010-12-10T00:00:00Z">10 December 2010</depDate>         <distDate date="2011-01-07T00:00:00Z">7 January 2011</distDate>       </distStmt>       <verStmt>         <version date="2011-01-07T00:00:00Z">1</version>       </verStmt>       <holdings URI="http://dx.doi.org/10.5255/UKDA-SN-6649-1" />     </citation>     <stdyInfo>       <subject>         <keyword>2004</keyword>         <keyword vocabURI="http://lod.data-archive.ac.uk/skoshasset/16ac0454-7965-4ccb-8501-475db941195c">ARRANGEMENT OF WORKING TIME</keyword>         <keyword vocabURI="http://lod.data-archive.ac.uk/skoshasset/8bbecbfd-57cf-497f-b4ac-b24833adb6de">EMPLOYEES</keyword>         <keyword vocabURI="http://lod.data-archive.ac.uk/skoshasset/ba600f08-9ae7-4ad2-8189-f800e75c48af">FLEXIBLE WORKING TIME</keyword>         <keyword vocabURI="http://lod.data-archive.ac.uk/skoshasset/a88887cd-0807-4b8e-aa66-045bea330bc5">GREAT BRITAIN</keyword>         <keyword vocabURI="http://lod.data-archive.ac.uk/skoshasset/fe582516-3658-4ed0-b48d-feeb9611b37b">JOB SATISFACTION</keyword>         <keyword vocabURI="http://lod.data-archive.ac.uk/skoshasset/474efddc-7b45-4190-a6e4-9685359fcfbe">MANAGERS</keyword>         <keyword vocabURI="http://lod.data-archive.ac.uk/skoshasset/04e82af3-e6ca-4600-ba3b-9837fe476ba5">WORKING CONDITIONS</keyword>         <keyword vocabURI="http://lod.data-archive.ac.uk/skoshasset/c6f043f6-5476-4dae-a35a-d011f9187bbe">WORK-LIFE BALANCE</keyword>         <topcClas>Industrial relations - Employment and labour</topcClas>       </subject>       <abstract><p>Abstract copyright UK Data Service and data collection copyright owner.</p><i>Additional Scales on High Involvement Management, Family-Friendly Management and Lean Production from the Workplace Employee Relations Survey, 2004</i> investigates how the implementation of such employment approaches can be linked to employee well-being and organisational performance. High involvement management (HIM) involves such organisational practices as team-working, flexible job descriptions and other arrangements which encourage greater flexibility and collaboration along with acquiring the skills and knowledge required to optimise working in teams. Lean production entails practices which facilitate the timely and efficient procurement and delivery of goods and services. Family-friendly policies are aimed at helping employees by providing flexitime working and access to facilities which support the achievement of an optimal work-life balance.<br> <br> This study used data from <i> Workplace Employee Relations Survey, 2004</i> (WERS 2004) (available from the UK Data Archive under SN 5294). Analysis procedures involved state-of-the-art statistical analysis, including latent variable analysis, multi-level modelling, path analysis and configuration analysis. The dataset deposited at the Archive includes four variables; one unique reference number which can be matched against the WERS 2004 data and 3 trait score variables.<br> <br> Further information can be found on the ESRC <a href="http://www.esrc.ac.uk/my-esrc/grants/RES-000-23-1482/read" title ="High Involvement Management, Employee Well-Being and Organisational Performance">High Involvement Management, Employee Well-Being and Organisational Performance</a> award web page.<br> </abstract>       <abstract><B>Main Topics</B>:<br>The dataset includes the following four variables:<ul><li><b>serno</b> - WERS2004 unique reference number </li><li><b>highinvolvmgt</b> - high involvement management latent trait score (de Menezes, Wood and Dritsaki, 2009)</li><li><b>jobdesign</b> - job design latent trait score</li><li><b>familyfriendly</b> - family-friendly management latent trait score</li></ul>The documentation includes more details about these variables.</abstract>       <sumDscr>         <collDate event="single" date="2004-01-01T00:00:00Z">2004</collDate>         <nation>Great Britain</nation>         <geogUnit>No spatial unit</geogUnit>         <anlyUnit>Individuals</anlyUnit>         <anlyUnit> Institutions/organisations</anlyUnit>         <universe>National</universe>         <universe>All establishments in Britain with five or more employees and operating in Sections D-O of the Standard Industrial Classification (SIC2003).
